title.narrative: Supporting and growing Palestinian start-ups in the Gaza strip

description.narrative:
Gaza strip has become a difficult place to find work with its 1.8M population on its 360 sq. meters (1), suffering limited land and sea access and strict border restrictions on movement and flow of goods and services into and from the strip. The economic situation has deteriorated over the years, which has resulted in the near collapse of most of the private sector, high poverty rates and extreme rates of unemployment. According to the Palestinian National MDG Report in 2010, 55.7% of the Palestinians in the Gaza strip are living below the poverty line with an unemployment rate of 39.3% in 2009 with the trend rising throughout 2010(2). The world bank has estimated the actual poverty rate in the case of not receiving any humanitarian aid and international funding, and stated that the needs of the Palestinians in the Gaza strip will rise to hit 79.4%(3).
Poverty rates among Palestinian households during 2007 totalled 34.5 %: 23.6 % for the West Bank and 55.7 % in Gaza Strip. The World Bank figures released in 2008 broadly reflect PCBS findings; they note that the crisis rate of poverty in the Gaza Strip meant that poverty figures rose overall. Unemployment increased to exceed extreme limits due to the political uncertainty and severe economic conditions since the year 2007 limits. According to Human Development Report in the OPT (published by UNDP, 2009/2010) The overall unemployment rate in the Occupied Palestinian Territories was 26.0% in 2008, however, it shows a high rate of 40.6% in the Gaza Strip comparing with 19.0% in the West Bank.
This project aims to reduce poverty and unemployment among young entrepreneurs through encouraging them to start their own sustainable businesses by transforming the innovative ideas of the entrepreneurs in Gaza strip into small businesses and projects through providing integrated packages of business development professional services and offering means of linking and matchmaking with the external markets and businesses, which will enhance the economic situation, reduce unemployment, create new sustainable jobs, products and services. The program also is aimed to build strategic linkages between business development programs, local and international businesses and firms along with the academic institutions.
The CIA World Fact book, accessed on 2 Nov, 2014 Ministry of Planning and administrative development , The Palestinian National Millennium Development Goals Progress Report- Sep. 2010 World Bank (2008) Palestinian Economic Prospects: Aid, Access and Reform, Sep. 2008

Incubator staff Academic institutions including Universities and Colleges in the Gaza strip Students and fresh graduates from Business Administration, Engineering and IT Faculties in Universities and colleges Young and female entrepreneurs and potential entrepreneurs from marginalized groups Existing small sized companies and start-ups

Output 1.2: Assessing the business development services provided by the incubators in Gaza Strip A report describing the progress and the indicators An assessment report about the services provided
Output 2.1: Incubating (and sustaining) 15 existing start-ups and providing incubation services until January, 2016. Number of start-ups sustained Sustaining a minimum of 15 existing start-ups
Output 2.2: Accelerating 10 businesses and sustaining 20 businesses by Dec, 2015 Number of accelerated and sustained businesses - Accelerated 10 start-ups (minimum) The % of approved business from women - About 50% of the accelerated/incubated groups will be women-based
Output 2.3: Providing coaching sessions for 25 competing groups (start-ups) by Dec, 2015. Number of business plans and ideas participating - Include 25 business plans to enter the camp Number of coaching hours provided - A collective of 200 coaching hours to be provided for 40 groups The number of attendees in networking sessions and meetings that BTI will have organized under the proposed project - Approving 15 high-potential business plans
Output 2.4: Providing advanced training on 4 modules for 25 competing groups (start-ups) by Dec, 2015 Number of training hours provided for incubated start-ups - Providing 36 training hours on 3 modules for 20 participating businesses, about 90% of participants are from marginalized groups, about 50% of participants are from women
Output 3.1: Holding sessions and meetings addressing start-up barriers, namely in registration and online payments, and recommending solutions for authorities to take action Number of meetings held - Holding a roundtable session and about 5 meetings with stakeholders from NGOs, educational sector and the private sector Stakeholders involved in meetings - Calling participants from NGOs, Official departments, Private Sector , Higher Education Institutes and Media agencies for policy meetings Number of white papers drafted supporting policies for removing business barriers - Finalizing white papers on "Registration" and "Online Payments" barriers for SMEs in Gaza strip and pushing authorities towards a resolution of these issues, Visiting international incubators/accelerators by 3 individuals and promoting Palestinian SMEs products and services
Output 3.2: Showcasing Start-ups progress and productions in a large-scale conference/expo by Dec, 2015 Number of conference/expo attendees - Welcoming at least 700 visitors to the conference/expo The number of successful matchmaking interactions between entrepreneurs and financiers - Matchmaking about more than 2 businesses with local and international investors.
